has been elected president
American League to Aid and Cooperate with Russia and will direct a nation-wide movement in
this country, backed by leading
citizens, to bring about a common
understanding between the peoples of Russia and the United
States. Daniel Willard, of the
Board of Trustees, and Dr. William H. Welch, of the Medical
School will assist in this movement.
Dr. Goodnow was asked to head
this new organization at a meeting of its executive committee in
the office of Senator Owen, of Oklahoma, last Thursday. He accepted. Herbert L. Carpenter, of
New York, was named as chairman of the executive committee.
Dr. Goodnow will have associated
with him men of national reputation in the professional and business world. Among them are Col.
William Boyce Thompson, of the
Red Cross Mission to Russia, who
was elected vice-president; Senator Borah, Senator Calder, Representative Cooper, Representative
Flood, Samuel Gompers, Melville
E. Stone, Oscar S. Strauss, Dr.
William H. Welch, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore
and Ohio; Senator John Sharp
Williams, and others. These men
have accepted places on the executive committee of the league and
will take an active interest in the
work Dr. Goodnow will undertake.
One of the first purposes of the
league will be to awaken the people
of the United States to the importance of the freedom of the
Russian people as it relates to the
future of this country and to the
permanent peace of the world. It
will also seek to acquaint the Russian people with this country's
sympathy and good will and its
willingness to help her in her present troubles.
Resolutions were adopted expressing confidence in the Russian
people and pledging the "energy
and full force" of the organization "toward effectively safeguarding our common liberty and toward
throwing off the yoke of autocratic
power to the end that the world
may enjoy a lasting peace and fair
dealing between all nations."
David Lawrence, Washington
correspondent of the New York

LEMMERT

Monthly Inspection on Monday.

The regular monthly inspections
was held last Monday on Homewood Field. The Battalion passed
in review before Major Guild and
the Staff, and was then inspected
in detail by tactical officers. A
marked improvement in the military appearance of the Corps has
been noted at each successive inspection, and on Monday very few
were reported for violations of
soldierly neatness. During the
latter part of the drill the lieutenants took charge of the companies,
and lastly the sergeants were
given a chance to command the
companies while the officers were
taught the manual of the saber.

ANNAPOLIS SHORT LINE

Exact models of the more complicated type of trenches used today by the Allies were constructed
last Tuesday on the sand tables.
Sand bags, wooden revetments,
and the like were employed just
as "over there." Another war
game was carried on at the same
time on the two big relief maps
with non-commissioned officers in
command of the battling forces.
A particularly sanguinary conflict was waged, for these veritable butchers hurled huge forces
directly into the face of a terrific
artillery and machine gun fire.

MAY 6, 1918

BALTIMORE, MD

The managing editor for this issue was Leo W. Simon.

Vacation Vocations.
With the arrival of the summer, comes the opportunity for college men to take an active part in helping the Government carry out
its war program. Attendance at the University during the college
year is the college man's business; but during the vacation he can help
directly, he can render real service. Now is the time to decide how
you will help. Don't wait until after examinations, when circumstances may make it too late to use you. If you want to help, find out
where you can do some good; don't spend the summer patriotically
by making flags and service buttons! The Government departments
need clerical workers and stenographers all the time. The farmers
are begging for agricultural workers, for every one they can get. The
Department of Labor, through its Employment Bureau, can place an
unlimited number of mechanics, skilled machinists, engineering students. The Emergency Fleet Corporation have let us know how
eagerly they desire more men, that there is room in the shipyards
for every college man. There is more than enough to do; we have been
shown the way! But whatever you do, decide now!

An Opportunity for Sophomores.

N. B. — IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENTS
The attention of undergraduates is called to the following
notices:
1. Every first-year student in the Academic Department
must at once inform his instructor in English Composition 1 of
his choice of a major subject in order that he may be assigned
an adviser.
2. Upon notificatidn of the appointment of an adviser, every
student who expects to return to the University next year,
whether in the Academic or Engineering Department, must consult with his adviser as to the course to be pursued. The student
(not the adviser) will then hand to the Registrar before the end
of May a list of the courses he wishes to take. Failu're to report
the courses before June 1 entails a fine of one dollar per day.
Changes in the course may be made by notification to the Registrar at any time before September 25, after that date only with
the approval of the Dean.
3. The Board of Collegiate Studies has decided to separate
the students into classes on the following basis:
Freshmen—Students who have not passed twenty-one points
for graduation.
Sophomores—Students who have to their credit twenty-one
points.
Juniors—Students who have to their credit fifty points.
Seniors—Students who have to their credit eighty points.
The records will represent the standing on October 7, 1918.
4. Students are reminded that all entrance conditions must
be removed before the beginning of the third year of residence,
and that failures in courses must be made up before the beginning of the autumn term, in order to count for graduation.
By order of:
DEAN BRUSH.

There are two men who have entered the service or are doing
Government work who have been authorized by the Office to play on
the lacrosse team.
The Student Council passed a resolution, favoring the adoption of
the undergraduate rule for Hopkins athletics.
There were not more than twenty-five men present at the meeting for the nomination of officers of the Athletic Association. The
officers and members of the Athletic Board are alone responsible for
athletic conditions at the University. The election of these officers
will be held on this Wednesday at 12.30.
There is a rumor that the Athletic Board is considering reengaging the football coach who has been employed for the last two
seasons.

Class of '20, it is up to you! It has been decided that you are
the only class eligible for the summer R. 0. T. C. Camp. Only those
who have completed two years of military training and agree to pursue the advanced course for two more years will be admitted; hence,
the Seniors, Juniors and Freshmen are eliminated.

Professor Lovejoy the Spokesman

President Poincaire, in receiving the members of the American
Labor Mission recently, said it
was a great advantage that so
many branches of industry were
represented by the mission. In
speaking of the war he said :
"France is a peace-loving nation, believing in the triumph of
right over might. It is not a question of Alsace-Lorraine, but a
question of militarism against democracy."
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of
Johns Hopkins University, replying in French, said:
"America has learned a great
lesson and now is whole-heartedly
in the war. The efforts of France
shall not be in vain. The American youth mustered into the army
will fight to retrieve the losses.
There can be no peace until the
end of German militarism."
"That's funny," mused the man
in the movie show.
"What is?" inquired his wife.
"I never saw that plot before."
—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 6, 1918.

I

NEWS OF HOPKINS MEN

11

The following letter, brimful of
pertinent news, is from Dorsey
Richardson, a former member of
THE NEW'S-LETTER staff. Richardson received his M. A.,in-absentia,
on Commemoration Day.
FRANCE, April 6, 1918.
THE EDITOR, THE NEWS-LETTER'
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
This being the anniversary of
the war from our point of view,
I think it may be of interest to
Hopkins people to know of some
of the recent J. H. U. men, who
are in this particular part of the
world just now.
Naturally, it is pretty hard for
one here to see many organizations besides his own, but I .have
found and heard of a few former
students, Victor Bridgman, '14,
is a captain in an artillery regiment close by us, as is also Alan
Campbell, ex-'14. The last time
I saw them, they were in good
shape. Whether George Gillet, '13,
now captain of Cavalry, is still
in France I cannot say. He was
on General Seibert's staff, •but
none in these parts have heard of
him lately.
In my regiment, Lieut. Philip
Rainer, who took some graduate
work in '07-08, is, along with me,
the Hopkins contingent. W. R.
Willoughby, son .of Dr. Willoughby, who was in the Lafayette Escadrille, has been commissioned
in the U. S. artillery, and is at
a training .z4tation over here, or
on the line. I am not sure which.
• Some of the Hopkins people
may be glad to know that "Billy"
Ward, the star Virginia half-back
for the past few years, won the
distinguished service cross for
bravery in action in the Somme.
As for the crowd that came into
the army when I did, Bob Merrick
is the only one I have heard of.
His regiment was at Douglas by
last reports. Howell, Gorman,
Wilson, Skinner and Brinton—
some of them may be here, but
I can't say for sure.
If it would not be too much
trouble, may I ask you to bundle
up a lot of this year's NEWS-LETrums and send them to me. Over
here I have not heard a word

about the University, and I feel the
lack of news keenly. Some one
wrote and told be that they gave
me an M. A. on Feburary 22, but
that is absolutely the only news
I have received. The papers will
be greatly appreciated.
Naturally, I cannot say where
I am or what I am doing—except
that it is pretty much what everybody else in these parts is busy
with. The only thing I can hope
for is to be home in time to see
us run Maryland State up and
down Homewood field on Thanksgiving Day of this year, and St.
John's the week before. Please
give my best regards to anyone
you see that I know; and don't
forget the papers.
Sincerely,
DORSEY RICHARDSON.
1st Lieut. 17th F. A.
A. E. F., France.

April 16, 1918.
Dear Dr. Brush:
I was mighty glad to get your
letter of March 13. Mail is coming somewhat more regularly than
it did at first. We are in our
second tour at the front. We
started for a rest camp about the
same time the big advance began
so it was imperative that we be
shot back into the line. Naturally
none of us wanted to be resting
when the biggest battle of the
war was going on. I haven't
heard a word of complaint.
We had a pretty lively time in
the last sector, two batteries getting as many shells as a battery
gets in the hottest of sectors.
We also got a good deal of gas.
The English masks are pretty
uncomfortable. One night we
thought we should have to sleep
in them but to our relief the 0. K.
signal was sounded soon after we
had adjusted them. In the last
sector I was in headquarters
company and had charge of the
1- t Battalion Reconnaisance Detail. It was a job with plenty of
-thrills" as I had to do a lot of

visiting batteries which were often
under fire, and I had several
rather exciting races with "210's."
(The shells fall very nearly in
the same area. It is distinctly
unwise to remain in that area,
and you hustle over it in record
time.) One day I was riding
down a camouflaged road quite
near the front when a shell lit
about 30 yards behind my horse.
I didult walk him much until I
got to a safer neighborhood. Another time the deserted village
in which we were located was
bombarded. I thought all ray
--clothes and other stuff which we
carry (and which is mighty hard
to replace over here) was going
up in small fragments. But on
going to my billet immediately
after the shelling, I found that
a house quite near had been struck
but mine was all right. I didn't
take long to move, however, not
knowing when the whiz-bangs
would begin again. Just a few
days before that we were aroused
at 5 A. M., after working half the
night on an abri to "police up"
for a distinguished Hopkins Alumnus who rolled into the village
at 7. He had expected to visit
one of our battery positions, but,
shelling near the battery made it
unwise.
While in the last sector we cooperated with a groupe (Battalion) of a crack French art.
regt. and our Battalion officers
messed with theirs. They surely
were attractive fellows—very interesting about their experiences
earlier in the war and at Verdun,
and most willing to help us. It
was an excellent opportunity to
learn French and I thought it a
contradiction to those who accuse
us of provincialism that five or
six of us could speak fairly intelligible French while very few of
the French Officers could speak
English. When we left the sector
they were very complimentary
about the courage and coolness
of our men under fire and said
• contact with our troops had done
much to improve the morale of
their men.
We had good fun marching for
three or four days—the country
is beautiful as you may know
from personal experience. The
Chicago Tribune said that the
Rainbow Division was in the Luneville sector. I don't reckon I'll be
court-martialed for repeating it.
This sector is very quiet in comparison to the last. The other
day ii went up to an observatory
in our front line trenches and had
a good view of "No Man's Land,"
the Roche front line and also of
some Boches who were ,walking
along a road behind their trenches. A splendid road leads up
to the front at this point lined on
both sides by magnificant shade
trees. Many of these trees are
terribly hacked and mutilated by
shell fire. Some of them—a yard
in diameter—are cut clean off.
About a week ago I asked the

ATHLETIC BOARD NOMINATIONS
Schmidt and Stanley Candidatesfor Presidency of Athletic Board—Election
Wednesday at 12.30—Student
Council Election Also.

A meeting for the nomination
of officers and delegates for the
Athletic Board for next year was
held in the C. E. Lecture Hall
last Wednesday at 12.30. The
election will be held this Wednesday at the same time and place.
A small crowd was present at the
meeting last week, but it is expected that practically every student will attend the election,which
will come immediately after the
military lecture. The list of nominees follows:
For President: Schmidt, Stanley.
For Vice-President: B. Smith,
Baxley.
For Secretary: T. J. Williams,
Coulter, Kirk.
For Recording Secretary: Wyckoff, G. Wagner.
For Senior Delegates—(3 to be
elected): J. K. Vickers, Smith,
Stanley, Schmidt, Cox.
For Junior Delegates—(2 to be
electe(1): G. Cattanack, Silberotein, Wyckoff, Bratt, Coleman,
Burger, Benson, Gardner, H.
Stewart.
For Sophomore Delegate — (1
to be elected): Brennan, Keyes,
Carey, E. Jones, Mulliken.
For Medical Delegate—(1 to be
elected): Firor, Sadtler, Sutton,
Purcell, Sheffey, Leadbetter.
For Alumni Delegates—(2 to be
elected): Dr. "Tom" Brown, Reahey Wolfe, Huntley Lloyd, George
Dorsey.
At the same time the President
of the Student Council is to be
elected from the three men nominated by the present Junior Class
at their last class meeting. These
three men are Chisholm, Kirk, and
Carneal. One will be elected President of the Council, and the other
two will be the Senior Delegates
for next year.

him out. It was a clean steal.
Purcell was not the only one
that starred and the highest honors perhaps must be handed to
"Charlie" Webb, the stocky right
fielder of the Hopkins aggregation. His three hits, one a threebagger, figured largely in the scoring, and his catch of Batty's line
.drive just inside the right field
foul line in the fifth inning
brought the crowd to their feet
and kept them talking about him
for the rest of the game. After
one was out in the fifth stanza,
Batty walked to the plate and
caught one of Welliver's fast ones
right on the nose. The ball traveled like a bullet just inside of the
foul line and was curving toward
the foul line mark. Webb was playing deep and at the crack of the
•bat he raced to his left and lunging forward he stuck out his
gloved hand and the ball hit it
and stuck. Charlie took two sommersaults after the catch and
came up with the ball still in his
hand. Every spectator pronounced
it the prettiest catch he had ever
seen and Webb was given a great
hand when he walked in to the
bench.
"Teddy" Welliver, Hopkins'
young star twirler, pitched a great
game and would have held the
Annapolitans scoreless but for errors made by his team mates.
Capt. "Dick" Benson was also in
the limelight. He caught every
man that tried to steal second,
except one. That steal was made
with a man on third and Littman
was drawn in to catch the ball to
prevent a score. He also caught
several high flies that were very
difficult chances.
It wasn't because the Hopkins
nine was so much better than the
St. John's team that they won,
but because they had the old fighting spirit. They played desperately and they played together,
fighting every inch of the way.
Although six miscues are marked
up against them, they tightened
up and played big league baseball
when errors meant runs. The team
was urged on to do their best by
the faithful rooters in the stands.
For the first tiine this year, the
Hopkins students got together and
gave yells for the team and every
individual on it. Despite the frequent showers the men stuck there
until the end and gave the team
a great hand when they ran off
the field champions of Maryland.
Hopkins was the first to score,
breaking the ice in the third period. After Cox had gotten out,
Webb found one of Smith's offerings to his liking and crashed it
out for a triple, crossing the plate
a second later when Bloomsburg
singled. Bloomsburg was thrown
out trying to steal second or Hopkins would have gotten two runs
in this inning, as Jones, the next
man up, got another three-bagger.

"Barn" Violates Food Regulations.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—It often happens that we
fail to see that which is closest
to us, while we can easily discern
the same thing at a distance.
While we are insisting in our
homes and outside on a strict
compliance with the requests of
the Food Administration, we do
not encourage it here at the University. For some reason or
other the Barn lunchroom still
sells wheat bread sandwiches on
wheatless day. This may be only
an oversight; certainly it should
be corrected. Perhaps the mere
calling of attention to the fact
will suffice to bring about a rectification of this condition.
JUNIOR.

has been elected president
American League to Aid and Cooperate with Russia and will direct a nation-wide movement in
this country, backed by leading
citizens, to bring about a common
understanding between the peoples of Russia and the United
States. Daniel Willard, of the
Board of Trustees, and Dr. William H. Welch, of the Medical
School will assist in this movement.
Dr. Goodnow was asked to head
this new organization at a meeting of its executive committee in
the office of Senator Owen, of Oklahoma, last Thursday. He accepted. Herbert L. Carpenter, of
New York, was named as chairman of the executive committee.
Dr. Goodnow will have associated
with him men of national reputation in the professional and business world. Among them are Col.
William Boyce Thompson, of the
Red Cross Mission to Russia, who
was elected vice-president; Senator Borah, Senator Calder, Representative Cooper, Representative
Flood, Samuel Gompers, Melville
E. Stone, Oscar S. Strauss, Dr.
William H. Welch, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore
and Ohio; Senator John Sharp
Williams, and others. These men
have accepted places on the executive committee of the league and
will take an active interest in the
work Dr. Goodnow will undertake.
One of the first purposes of the
league will be to awaken the people
of the United States to the importance of the freedom of the
Russian people as it relates to the
future of this country and to the
permanent peace of the world. It
will also seek to acquaint the Russian people with this country's
sympathy and good will and its
willingness to help her in her present troubles.
Resolutions were adopted expressing confidence in the Russian
people and pledging the "energy
and full force" of the organization "toward effectively safeguarding our common liberty and toward
throwing off the yoke of autocratic
power to the end that the world
may enjoy a lasting peace and fair
dealing between all nations."
David Lawrence, Washington

Monthly Inspection on Monday.

The regular monthly inspections
was held last Monday on Homewood Field. The Battalion passed
in review before Major Guild and
the Staff, and was then inspected
in detail by tactical officers. A
marked improvement in the military appearance of the Corps has
been noted at each successive inspection, and on Monday very few
were reported for violations of
soldierly neatness. During the
latter part of the drill the lieutenants took charge of the companies,
and lastly the sergeants were
given a chance to command the
companies while the officers were
taught the manual of the saber.

directly into the face of a terrific
artillery and machine gun fire.

BALTIMORE, MD

The managing editor for this issue was Leo W. Simon.

Vacation Vocations.
With the arrival of the summer, comes the opportunity for college men to take an active part in helping the Government carry out
its war program. Attendance at the University during the college
year is the college man's business; but during the vacation he can help
directly, he can render real service. Now is the time to decide how
you will help. Don't wait until after examinations, when circumstances may make it too late to use you. If you want to help, find out
where you can do some good; don't spend the summer patriotically
by making flags and service buttons! The Government departments
need clerical workers and stenographers all the time. The farmers
are begging for agricultural workers, for every one they can get. The
Department of Labor, through its Employment Bureau, can place an
unlimited number of mechanics, skilled machinists, engineering students. The Emergency Fleet Corporation have let us know how
eagerly they desire more men, that there is room in the shipyards
for every college man. There is more than enough to do; we have been
shown the way! But whatever you do, decide now!

An Opportunity for Sophomores.

N. B. — IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENTS
The attention of undergraduates is called to the following
notices:
1. Every first-year student in the Academic Department
must at once inform his instructor in English Composition 1 of
his choice of a major subject in order that he may be assigned
an adviser.
2. Upon notificatidn of the appointment of an adviser, every
student who expects to return to the University next year,
whether in the Academic or Engineering Department, must consult with his adviser as to the course to be pursued. The student
(not the adviser) will then hand to the Registrar before the end
of May a list of the courses he wishes to take. Failu're to report
the courses before June 1 entails a fine of one dollar per day.
Changes in the course may be made by notification to the Registrar at any time before September 25, after that date only with
the approval of the Dean.
3. The Board of Collegiate Studies has decided to separate
the students into classes on the following basis:
Freshmen—Students who have not passed twenty-one points
for graduation.
Sophomores—Students who have to their credit twenty-one
points.
Juniors—Students who have to their credit fifty points.
Seniors—Students who have to their credit eighty points.
The records will represent the standing on October 7, 1918.
4. Students are reminded that all entrance conditions must
be removed before the beginning of the third year of residence,
and that failures in courses must be made up before the beginning of the autumn term, in order to count for graduation.
By order of:
DEAN BRUSH.

There are two men who have entered the service or are doing
Government work who have been authorized by the Office to play on
the lacrosse team.
The Student Council passed a resolution, favoring the adoption of
the undergraduate rule for Hopkins athletics.
There were not more than twenty-five men present at the meeting for the nomination of officers of the Athletic Association. The
officers and members of the Athletic Board are alone responsible for
athletic conditions at the University. The election of these officers
will be held on this Wednesday at 12.30.
There is a rumor that the Athletic Board is considering reengaging the football coach who has been employed for the last two
seasons.

Professor Lovejoy the Spokesman

President Poincaire, in receiving the members of the American
Labor Mission recently, said it
was a great advantage that so
many branches of industry were
represented by the mission. In
speaking of the war he said :
"France is a peace-loving nation, believing in the triumph of
right over might. It is not a question of Alsace-Lorraine, but a
question of militarism against democracy."
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of
Johns Hopkins University, replying in French, said:
"America has learned a great
lesson and now is whole-heartedly
in the war. The efforts of France
shall not be in vain. The American youth mustered into the army
will fight to retrieve the losses.
There can be no peace until the
end of German militarism."
"That's funny," mused the man
in the movie show.
"What is?" inquired his wife.
"I never saw that plot before."
—Ex.

I

NEWS OF HOPKINS MEN

11

The following letter, brimful of
pertinent news, is from Dorsey
Richardson, a former member of
THE NEW'S-LETTER staff. Richardson received his M. A.,in-absentia,
on Commemoration Day.
FRANCE, April 6, 1918.
THE EDITOR, THE NEWS-LETTER'
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
This being the anniversary of
the war from our point of view,
I think it may be of interest to
Hopkins people to know of some
of the recent J. H. U. men, who
are in this particular part of the
world just now.
Naturally, it is pretty hard for
one here to see many organizations besides his own, but I .have
found and heard of a few former
students, Victor Bridgman, '14,
is a captain in an artillery regiment close by us, as is also Alan
Campbell, ex-'14. The last time
I saw them, they were in good
shape. Whether George Gillet, '13,
now captain of Cavalry, is still
in France I cannot say. He was
on General Seibert's staff, •but
none in these parts have heard of
him lately.
In my regiment, Lieut. Philip
Rainer, who took some graduate
work in '07-08, is, along with me,
the Hopkins contingent. W. R.
Willoughby, son .of Dr. Willoughby, who was in the Lafayette Escadrille, has been commissioned
in the U. S. artillery, and is at
a training .z4tation over here, or
on the line. I am not sure which.
• Some of the Hopkins people
may be glad to know that "Billy"
Ward, the star Virginia half-back
for the past few years, won the
distinguished service cross for
bravery in action in the Somme.
As for the crowd that came into
the army when I did, Bob Merrick
is the only one I have heard of.
His regiment was at Douglas by
last reports. Howell, Gorman,
Wilson, Skinner and Brinton—
some of them may be here, but
I can't say for sure.
If it would not be too much
trouble, may I ask you to bundle
up a lot of this year's NEWS-LETrums and send them to me. Over
here I have not heard a word

about the University, and I feel the
lack of news keenly. Some one
wrote and told be that they gave
me an M. A. on Feburary 22, but
that is absolutely the only news
I have received. The papers will
be greatly appreciated.
Naturally, I cannot say where
I am or what I am doing—except
that it is pretty much what everybody else in these parts is busy
with. The only thing I can hope
for is to be home in time to see
us run Maryland State up and
down Homewood field on Thanksgiving Day of this year, and St.
John's the week before. Please
give my best regards to anyone
you see that I know; and don't
forget the papers.
Sincerely,
DORSEY RICHARDSON.
1st Lieut. 17th F. A.
A. E. F., France.

April 16, 1918.
Dear Dr. Brush:
I was mighty glad to get your
letter of March 13. Mail is coming somewhat more regularly than
it did at first. We are in our
second tour at the front. We
started for a rest camp about the
same time the big advance began
so it was imperative that we be
shot back into the line. Naturally
none of us wanted to be resting
when the biggest battle of the
war was going on. I haven't
heard a word of complaint.
We had a pretty lively time in
the last sector, two batteries getting as many shells as a battery
gets in the hottest of sectors.
We also got a good deal of gas.
The English masks are pretty
uncomfortable. One night we
thought we should have to sleep
in them but to our relief the 0. K.
signal was sounded soon after we
had adjusted them. In the last
sector I was in headquarters
company and had charge of the
1- t Battalion Reconnaisance Detail. It was a job with plenty of

visiting batteries which were often
under fire, and I had several
rather exciting races with "210's."
(The shells fall very nearly in
the same area. It is distinctly
unwise to remain in that area,
and you hustle over it in record
time.) One day I was riding
down a camouflaged road quite
near the front when a shell lit
about 30 yards behind my horse.
I didult walk him much until I
got to a safer neighborhood. Another time the deserted village
in which we were located was
bombarded. I thought all ray
--clothes and other stuff which we
carry (and which is mighty hard
to replace over here) was going
up in small fragments. But on
going to my billet immediately
after the shelling, I found that
a house quite near had been struck
but mine was all right. I didn't
take long to move, however, not
knowing when the whiz-bangs
would begin again. Just a few
days before that we were aroused
at 5 A. M., after working half the
night on an abri to "police up"
for a distinguished Hopkins Alumnus who rolled into the village
at 7. He had expected to visit
one of our battery positions, but,
shelling near the battery made it
unwise.
While in the last sector we cooperated with a groupe (Battalion) of a crack French art.
regt. and our Battalion officers
messed with theirs. They surely
were attractive fellows—very interesting about their experiences
earlier in the war and at Verdun,
and most willing to help us. It
was an excellent opportunity to
learn French and I thought it a
contradiction to those who accuse
us of provincialism that five or
six of us could speak fairly intelligible French while very few of
the French Officers could speak
English. When we left the sector
they were very complimentary
about the courage and coolness
of our men under fire and said
• contact with our troops had done
much to improve the morale of
their men.
We had good fun marching for
three or four days—the country
is beautiful as you may know
from personal experience. The
Chicago Tribune said that the
Rainbow Division was in the Luneville sector. I don't reckon I'll be
court-martialed for repeating it.
This sector is very quiet in comparison to the last. The other
day ii went up to an observatory
in our front line trenches and had
a good view of "No Man's Land,"
the Roche front line and also of
some Boches who were ,walking
along a road behind their trenches. A splendid road leads up
to the front at this point lined on
both sides by magnificant shade
trees. Many of these trees are
terribly hacked and mutilated by
shell fire. Some of them—a yard
in diameter—are cut clean off.

ATHLETIC BOARD NOMINATIONS
Schmidt and Stanley Candidatesfor Presidency of Athletic Board—Election
Wednesday at 12.30—Student
Council Election Also.

A meeting for the nomination
of officers and delegates for the
Athletic Board for next year was
held in the C. E. Lecture Hall
last Wednesday at 12.30. The
election will be held this Wednesday at the same time and place.
A small crowd was present at the
meeting last week, but it is expected that practically every student will attend the election,which
will come immediately after the
military lecture. The list of nominees follows:
For President: Schmidt, Stanley.
For Vice-President: B. Smith,
Baxley.
For Secretary: T. J. Williams,
Coulter, Kirk.
For Recording Secretary: Wyckoff, G. Wagner.
For Senior Delegates—(3 to be
elected): J. K. Vickers, Smith,
Stanley, Schmidt, Cox.
For Junior Delegates—(2 to be
electe(1): G. Cattanack, Silberotein, Wyckoff, Bratt, Coleman,
Burger, Benson, Gardner, H.
Stewart.
For Sophomore Delegate — (1
to be elected): Brennan, Keyes,
Carey, E. Jones, Mulliken.
For Medical Delegate—(1 to be
elected): Firor, Sadtler, Sutton,
Purcell, Sheffey, Leadbetter.
For Alumni Delegates—(2 to be
elected): Dr. "Tom" Brown, Reahey Wolfe, Huntley Lloyd, George
Dorsey.
At the same time the President
of the Student Council is to be
elected from the three men nominated by the present Junior Class
at their last class meeting. These
three men are Chisholm, Kirk, and
Carneal. One will be elected President of the Council, and the other
two will be the Senior Delegates
for next year.

him out. It was a clean steal.
Purcell was not the only one
that starred and the highest honors perhaps must be handed to
"Charlie" Webb, the stocky right
fielder of the Hopkins aggregation. His three hits, one a threebagger, figured largely in the scoring, and his catch of Batty's line
.drive just inside the right field
foul line in the fifth inning
brought the crowd to their feet
and kept them talking about him
for the rest of the game. After
one was out in the fifth stanza,
Batty walked to the plate and
caught one of Welliver's fast ones
right on the nose. The ball traveled like a bullet just inside of the
foul line and was curving toward
the foul line mark. Webb was playing deep and at the crack of the
•bat he raced to his left and lunging forward he stuck out his
gloved hand and the ball hit it
and stuck. Charlie took two sommersaults after the catch and
came up with the ball still in his
hand. Every spectator pronounced
it the prettiest catch he had ever
seen and Webb was given a great
hand when he walked in to the
bench.
"Teddy" Welliver, Hopkins'
young star twirler, pitched a great
game and would have held the
Annapolitans scoreless but for errors made by his team mates.
Capt. "Dick" Benson was also in
the limelight. He caught every
man that tried to steal second,
except one. That steal was made
with a man on third and Littman
was drawn in to catch the ball to
prevent a score. He also caught
several high flies that were very
difficult chances.
It wasn't because the Hopkins
nine was so much better than the
St. John's team that they won,
but because they had the old fighting spirit. They played desperately and they played together,
fighting every inch of the way.
Although six miscues are marked
up against them, they tightened
up and played big league baseball
when errors meant runs. The team
was urged on to do their best by
the faithful rooters in the stands.
For the first tiine this year, the
Hopkins students got together and
gave yells for the team and every
individual on it. Despite the frequent showers the men stuck there
until the end and gave the team
a great hand when they ran off
the field champions of Maryland.
Hopkins was the first to score,
breaking the ice in the third period. After Cox had gotten out,
Webb found one of Smith's offerings to his liking and crashed it
out for a triple, crossing the plate
a second later when Bloomsburg
singled. Bloomsburg was thrown
out trying to steal second or Hopkins would have gotten two runs
in this inning, as Jones, the next
man up, got another three-bagger.

ending the inning.
Hopkins tied the count in the
sixth when Purcell stole home, but
St. John's again went out in front
in the seventh. Their one-run
lead didn't last long, however, as
Hopkins shooed four runners
across the plate in their half of
the same inning. St. John's was
unable to tally any more, but Hopkins increased their total to eight
in the eighth period.
To say the victory was pleasing
to the Hopkins team is putting it
mildly, for St. John's came out to

and by comparative scores it

McCALLISTER'S

"Barn" Violates Food Regulations.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—It often happens that we
fail to see that which is closest
to us, while we can easily discern
the same thing at a distance.
While we are insisting in our
homes and outside on a strict
compliance with the requests of
the Food Administration, we do
not encourage it here at the University. For some reason or
other the Barn lunchroom still
sells wheat bread sandwiches on
wheatless day. This may be only
an oversight; certainly it should
be corrected. Perhaps the mere
calling of attention to the fact
will suffice to bring about a rectification of this condition.
JUNIOR.
